Authors: S. Sharma; D. Sahu; R. Narayanan; S. Kar; R. D. Tarey; A. Ganguli; M. Bandyopadhyay; A. Chakraborty; M. J. Singh
Author Affiliations: Indian Institute of Technology Delhi, New Delhi, India; Indian Institute of Technology Delhi, New Delhi, India; Indian Institute of Technology Delhi, New Delhi, India; Indian Institute of Technology Delhi, New Delhi, India; Indian Institute of Technology Delhi, New Delhi, India; Indian Institute of Technology Delhi, New Delhi, India; Institute for Plasma Research, Ahmedabad, Gujarat, India; Institute for Plasma Research, Ahmedabad, Gujarat, India; Institute for Plasma Research, Ahmedabad, Gujarat, India
Publication Title: 2020 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science (ICOPS)
Abstract: In the present work, hydrogen plasma was investigated in a large volume plasma chamber (dia: 1.0 m and height: 1.0 m). Plasma was produced in an indigenously made compact size ECR plasma source1, 2, (dia: 0.09 m, length: 0.11 m) located coaxially within an NdFeB ring magnet assembly, placed at the center of the top dome of the plasma chamber. The magnetic field inside the source generates the ECR zone to permit absorption of the incoming microwave at 2.45 GHz for plasma heating, and extends as a diverging field into the large chamber. Plasma from the source flows along magnetic field to form a beam–like column near the source. Langmuir probe measurements along the chamber axis ($z$) at pressures 1–3 mTorr and input power 400 W show that the plasma density ($n_{e}$) decays rapidly up to $z=20\ \text{cm}$ from the source mouth ($\mathrm{z}=0$) followed by a slow decay thereafter towards the bottom of the chamber. The initial decay profile tracks the axial magnetic field profile closely confirming the $n/B$ scaling obeyed by hydrogen plasma as observed earlier in a smaller vessel3. Radial measurements taken at different $z$ planes show good radial uniformity away from the source. At $z=70\ \text{cm}, n_{e}\approx 3.5-4.0\times 10^{10}\ \text{cm}^{-3}$ and $T_{e}\approx 1-2\ \text{eV}$ over 40 cm radius at ≈ 3 mTorr pressure and 400 W power. Studies showed increase in $n_{e}$ with the pressure, although increasing the microwave power did not alter the density or temperature significantly. The good radial uniformity and the low $T_{e}$ could be useful for extraction of H− beams. Results from these experiments will be presented in this manuscript.

Abstract: A model of multi-layered plane media with arbitrary boundaries has been proposed in this abstract, with which the dyadic Green's functions with the combination of metal and infinite radiation boundary can be solved with explicit form. Field-matching methods with the dyadic Green's function of multi-layered plane media were used for analyzing the high frequency characteristics of a meander line slow wave structure (ML-SWS) with or without dielectric for supporting the meander line (ML). The dispersion characteristics and coupling impedance of the ML-SWS calculated with the theory are in good agreement with those obtained by HFSS code, in which the relative error between them is under 7%. The effects of the metal shield and the thickness variation on dispersion of the ML-SWS can be considered with the theoretical model. The overlapping and crossing of adjacent modes were discussed for investigating the effects of adjacent modes on high frequency characteristics due to the variation of the structure size and mode order number, which show that the band gap of the dispersions may disappear when two half-period structures are symmetrical to each other for the adjacent two slow wave modes or the thickness of the ML is increased to some value for a fast wave mode and a slow wave mode. In addition, some problems easily confused with simulation methods can be effectively solved with the proposed method and the some obtained results are helpful for improving the flatness of the coupling impedance in operating frequency band for the design of the ML-SWS.

Document Title: Electron Heating in Capacitively Coupled Discharges of Complex Chemistry
Authors: J. T. Gudmundsson; A. Proto; G. Skarphedinsson
Author Affiliations: Department of Space and Plasma Physics, KTH Royal Institute of Technology, Stockholm, Sweden; Science Institute, University of Iceland, Reykjavik, Iceland; Science Institute, University of Iceland, Reykjavik, Iceland
Publication Title: 2020 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science (ICOPS)
Abstract: Here, we explore the spatio-temporal variation of the electron heating mechanism and the electron energy distribution in capacitively coupled discharges of three different chemistries. We study an electropositive argon discharge, weakly electronegative oxygen discharge and highly electronegative chlorine discharge at operating pressure of 10 mTorr and 50 mTorr for driving frequencies of 13.56 and 27.12 MHz. We apply the 1d-3v particle-in-cell Monte Carlo collision code oopd1 for the study. For the argon discharge the electron heating appears mainly in the sheath region while the chlorine discharge exhibits significant drift-ambipolar electron heating contribution within the electronegative core [1]. At 10 mTorr the oxygen discharge shows significant contribution from drift- ambipolar heating within the electronegative core at 13.56 MHz while the electron heating appears only in the sheath regions at 27.12 MHz and at 50 mTorr stochasting electron heating in the sheath region dominates. We discuss the heating mode transitions in the oxygen discharge as the pressure, electrode spacing, and operating frequency are varied [2], [3]. The oxygen discharge is detachment dominated while the chlorine discharge is ion-ion recombination dominated and this has a significant influence on the discharge properties. In the oxygen discharge the electronegativity increases with decreasing pressure while in the chlorine discharge the electronegativity increases with increasing pressure.

Abstract: Controlling the magnetic properties of materials is important for applications like magnetization switching, spin torque oscillators etc. Introduction of defects into materials has been demonstrated to change properties like damping and spin to charge conversion [1], [2]. Defect engineering in materials can be achieved by exposing to magnetic materials to high energy plasma. In the present study, 100 nm CoFeTaZr thin film was exposed to different shots of a large-volume slow-focus-mode dense plasma focus device to induce defects and modulate the magnetic properties like damping, anisotropy. The plasma temperature and density were studied using a faraday cup to tune the penetration depth of the ions in the magnetic material. The ferromagnetic resonance spectra of the samples with different ion doses were studied using impedance measurements in the frequency range of 1.6 GHz to 2.50 GHz. It was seen that the Gilberts damping factor, effective magnetization and anisotropic magnetization could be modulated with implantation using dense plasma focus.

Abstract: Atmospheric microplasma (AMP) has gained increasing interest in the past decades due to its simplicity, low temperature, high electron density and abundant active rations. It has been applied in various fields including material synthesis, surface modification, waste purification, and biomaterial deactivation etc. In material synthesis, AMP has successfully fabricated various nanoparticles, especially metals, however, the uniformity and controllability of the fabrication is still a big challenge. In this work, $\text{Pt}_{3}$ Co nanoflowers and Fe-Pt nanoparticles are fabricated by AMP. The effect of fabrication parameters (i.e. plasma discharging duration and components of electrolysis etc.) on the nanostructure properties is studied, and the mechanism of nanoflower formation is discussed. $\text{Pt}_{3}$ Co nanoflowers show promising electrochemical properties to be potentially applied as catalysts in applications like fuel cells and lithium batteries. Fe-Pt nanoparticles show nearly superparamagnetic properties to be potentially utilized in drug delivery and microfluidics.

Publication Title: 2020 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science (ICOPS)
Abstract: Inductively and capacitively coupled plasmas (ICP and CCP) are widely used in semiconductor device fabrication for a variety of etching and deposition processes. ICPs are typically used for metal and conductor etching while CCPs are typically used for dielectric etching. Decisions on these different applications of ICPs and CCPs were made largely on generations of devices whose characteristics are quite different from today's devices. In particular, high aspect ratio (HAR) devices (aspect ratios now exceeding 100) have more demanding requirements for anisotropy of incident ions and profile control, and less need for selectivity. Given these changing requirements, re-examination of the benefits and detriments of ICP vs. CCP for dielectric etching would provide needed guidance.

Document Title: A Comparison of Velocity Skin Effect Modeling with 2-D Transient and 3-D Quasi-Transient Finite Element Methods
Authors: N. Tosun; H. Polat; D. Ceylan; O. Keysan
Author Affiliations: Middle East Technical University Ankara, Turkey; Middle East Technical University Ankara, Turkey; Middle East Technical University Ankara, Turkey; Middle East Technical University Ankara, Turkey
Publication Title: 2020 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science (ICOPS)
Abstract: Analysis of the velocity skin effect in electromagnetic launchers requires a 3-D transient finite element method, unlike magnetic skin and proximity effects. However, large speeds with velocity skin effect dominance cause convergence problems when moving or deformed mesh physics are used in a transient FEM in the 3-D analysis. Commercial finite element codes are unable to solve the electromagnetic aspects of a launch using a transient solver in 3-D due to the aforementioned challenges. However, 2-D approximation suits well to model VSE even with commercial software. Such approximation overestimates VSE resistance due to the error comes from the assumption of infinitely high rail height. In this study, we used a quasi- transient 3-D FEM model where the conductivity of the air- armature region is varied to emulate the movement of the armature to invest the accuracy of the 2-D approximation. Results have shown that using 2-D approximation, the VSE resistance is overestimated by nearly 40%. The proposed VSE calculation model has been included in the EML model, and simulation results compared for experimental results with different electromagnetic launchers, EMFY-l and EMFY-2, and showed good agreement.

Document Title: Effect of Aberrations in Focusing Elements on Femtosecond Filaments
Authors: S. A. Nalam; S. S. Harsha; G. M. Kumar; P. P. Kiran
Author Affiliations: Advanced Centre for Research in High Energy Materials (ACRHEM), University of Hyderabad, Hyderabad, India; Advanced Centre for Research in High Energy Materials (ACRHEM), University of Hyderabad, Hyderabad, India; Advanced Centre for Research in High Energy Materials (ACRHEM), University of Hyderabad, Hyderabad, India; School of Physics, University of Hyderabad, Hyderabad, India
Publication Title: 2020 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science (ICOPS)
Abstract: Propagation of intense femtosecond pulses through atmosphere leads to the formation of an ionized plasma channel initiated by the dramatic self-collapse of the optical pulse due to Kerr mediated self-focusing which leads to an exponential increase in on-axis intensity. The balancing interplay of the intensity dependent Kerr self-focusing, and plasma induced defocusing, leads to a soliton like propagation of energy confined within a periodic plasma channel which is called a filament1. The onset of this phenomenon can be accelerated by using focusing optics which minimizes the distance and pulse energy requirement at which the filament generation is initiated. The generation of filament allows us to clamp the beam spot size and intensity over long distance of propagation which is very desirable for LIDAR applications. Any spatial or temporal distortion of the focused femtosecond laser beam due to the focusing elements has serious implications on the shape and intensity of the filament produced. Here, we present the results of our study on the effects of aberrations associated with different focusing elements on the nature of filament generated. We used both transmitting optics (achromat, thin and thick plano-convex lens) and Reflective optics (Off-axis parabolic mirror (OAPM)). Of these focusing elements the OAPM has the least aberrations (Spherical, chromatic and GDD induced) and thick lens has the most. We measured the atomic emissions from the filament and the supercontinuum generated using a USB spectrometer and the spatial extent using a CCD and DSLR camera. Based on the spectral measurements we estimated the peak filament intensities2 and GDD induced by each optical element. The surprising observation was that the thick lens with the most aberrations performed on par with the OAPM to produce the most intense filament. The thick lens had another advantage where the spatial extent of the filament (length and width) was also large compared to that of the OAPM. In applications like LIBS or white light LIDAR where one looks for strong emissions from the filament (large emission profile), the filament generated from the thick lens becomes highly desirable.

Abstract: On order to begin a detailed study on the Hybrid X-pinch to investigate the process behind the micropinch formation and confirm whether or not radiative collapse is the underlying process, we want a single, strong X-ray burst from the hybrid X-pinch at a reproducible time with $\mathrm{a}\pm 1$ ns accuracy. An optimization study was done for the following materials: Al, Ag, Mo, and Ti by changing the gap distance between the two conical electrodes. Different diameters were used in order to keep the mass per unit length the same. It appears that 0.5-1.5 mm gap was satisfactory to assure a single micropinch from a 300 kA, 50 ns rise time current pulse on the XP pulsed power generator. In addition, a time optimization study was carried on Ti wires, more than 50% of the shots produced X-rays at a consistent time. Time consistency was achieved by varying the gap distance and changing the wire diameter. It was found that smaller diameter wires with larger electrode gap distances were more consistent. We are also in the process of expanding this study to include more data points, as well as other load wire materials.

Document Title: Numerical Modeling of Rf Magnetron Discharges
Authors: D. Eremin; B. Berger; D. Engel; M. Oberberg; C. Woelfel; J. Lunze; P. Awakowicz; J. Schulze; R. P. Brinkmann
Author Affiliations: Bochum, Germany; Bochum, Germany; Bochum, Germany; Bochum, Germany; Bochum, Germany; Bochum, Germany; Bochum, Germany; Bochum, Germany; Bochum, Germany
Publication Title: 2020 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science (ICOPS)
Abstract: Rf magnetron discharges offer a number of advantages for the sputtering technology, such as the ability to be used for a virtually arbitrary target type. From the theoretical point of view, they represent a transition between the physics of the rf capacitively coupled discharges and the dc magnetron discharges. However, unlike their better-known counterparts, the rf magnetrons are less studied. In the present work we use an implicit energy-conserving 2d3v PIC/MCC code to model an rf magnetron investigated experimentally at the Ruhr University Bochum. Under assumptions of the axial symmetry and the insignificance of instabilities (indicated by experimental observations for the chosen operating regime), the simulations were conducted in r-z cylindrical geometry. The results demonstrated the importance of realistic reactor geometry representation in the code (including, e.g., the reactor side chamber) to achieve a good agreement with experimentally measured values of the dc self-bias, which was carried out with a strongly non-uniform mapped computational grid resolving the areas where essential phenomena were expected. Special emphasis in the present work was put on studying the rf modulated electron dynamics, which was strongly non-uniform due to the magnetron static magnetic field, featuring areas of inhibited transport across the magnetic field lines above the racetrack and CCP-like sheath phenomena where the magnetic field lines were almost perpendicular to the target. The rich electron power absorption dynamics obtained in the simulations could be explained by an interplay of such phenomena as the electric field reversal during the sheath collapse, influence of the ambipolar electric field, energization of the ion-induced secondary electrons by the sheath voltage, energetic electron beam generation by the sheath expansion for weak magnetic fields, and ohmic heating. The excitation dynamics provided by the simulations agreed reasonably well with the corresponding experimental observations.

Document Title: Production of Hydrogen Plasma by Compact ECR Source for Efficient Volume Generation of H− Ions
Authors: P. Singh; D. Sahu; R. Narayanan; A. Ganguli; S. Kar; R. D. Tarey
Author Affiliations: Centre for Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology Delhi, New Delhi, India; Centre for Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology Delhi, New Delhi, India; Centre for Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology Delhi, New Delhi, India; Centre for Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology Delhi, New Delhi, India; Centre for Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology Delhi, New Delhi, India; Centre for Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology Delhi, New Delhi, India
Publication Title: 2020 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science (ICOPS)
Abstract: Hydrogen plasma produced inside a compact ECR plasma source (CEPS)1 was allowed to expand into a large expansion chamber (dia. ≈ 50 cm, length ≈ 75 cm). Plasma parameters were measured using an on-axis Langmuir Probe. The CEPS uses NdFeB ring magnets with a complex field structure that has a magnetic mirror trap near the ECR zone followed by an on-axis magnetic null within the source region, and a monotonically decreasing field in the expansion chamber. Typically, at ≈ 600 W microwave power (2.45 GHz), 0.3–2 mTorr hydrogen pressure, the plasma density $n\approx 10^{10}\ \text{cm}^{-3}$ and electron temperature $T_{\mathrm{e}}\approx 25\ \ \text{eV}$ in the expansion chamber near the source, while further downstream $n$ and $T_{\mathrm{e}}$ are reduced to ≈ 109 cm−3 and 5 eV, respectively2. However, for 3–10 mTorr the plasma contains two electron populations - a high density, cold, bulk population and a low-density, warm population ($n_{w}/n\approx 0.01;\ T_{w}/T_{e}\approx 10$). Another feature observed at the higher pressures is that $T_{\mathrm{e}}$ cools to less than 1 eV about ≈ 30 cm from the source mouth. Such low $T_{\mathrm{e}}$ bulk electrons are important for generation of H− ions by the volume production mode, which may be preferred over the caesiated grid method due to maintenance issues associated with the latter3. An interesting feature of the plasma is that the normalized plasma density and magnetic field profiles overlap fairly accurately indicating very little cross-field transport of the hydrogen plasma. In general, one finds from the experiments that the nature of the CEPS magnetic field is such as to promote efficient electron heating and high $T_{\mathrm{e}}$, which are not desirable for volume production of H− ions. To achieve the latter, another field configuration that eliminates the adverse effects of the magnetic mirror and the null has been set up and results from the latter configuration will be presented at the conference.

Document Title: Experimental Studies of Electron Emission and Gas Breakdown for Nanoscale Diodes at Atmospheric Pressure
Authors: H. Wang; R. S. Brayfield; A. M. Darr; A. M. Loveless; A. L. Garner
Author Affiliations: Purdue University, West Lafayette, IN; Purdue University, West Lafayette, IN; Purdue University, West Lafayette, IN; Purdue University, West Lafayette, IN; Purdue University, West Lafayette, IN
Publication Title: 2020 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science (ICOPS)
Abstract: The continuous reduction in electronic device size at vacuum and atmospheric pressure necessitates appropriate characterization of gas breakdown for device reliability. Traditionally, gas breakdown is driven by Townsend avalanche by Paschen's law. Reducing gap distance at atmospheric pressure creates high electric fields at the cathode that strip electrons by field emission (FE) to ionize neutral gas atoms; the resulting positive space-charge adds to the secondary electron emission1. A matched asymptotic analysis predicts that breakdown voltage decreases linearly with decreasing gap distance when FE drives breakdown. However, a recent theory unifying FE with space-charge limited emission in vacuum (SCLEV) and with collisions predicts that FE will transition directly to SCLEV at ~250 nm for nitrogen.

Abstract: Plasma Facing Component materials are exposed to the harshest environmental conditions inside any nuclear fusion device. Tungsten is the most suitable candidate due to its high melting point, good ablation resistance, good thermal conductivity, low hydrogen retention etc. This would enable the use of these materials as first wall materials for fusion reactors. In the present study, the surface of the tungsten substrates are modified by exposing the tungsten substrates with different RF plasmas and its performance under fusion conditions. Two different strategies were adopted here to improve its surface properties - surface nanostructurization and thin film deposition which were achieved using an RF plasma system and anode ablation in a dense plasma focus device respectively. The fusion conditions were simulated by operating the dense plasma focus device in a deuterium environment in optimal operating conditions. The material characterization before and after exposure to deuterium plasma was done using scanning electron microscopy, atomic force microscopy, x-ray photoelectron spectroscopy and a nanoindentor.

Univ. of Sao Paulo, SP, Brazil; University of New Mexico, Albuquerque, NM, USA
Publication Title: 2020 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science (ICOPS)
Abstract: High power RF generation using alternative methods based on a non-conventional technique has been investigated recently. In general, conventional based-tube RF generation requires vacuum and heating filament, which consumes space and power. In our research, it is envisaged the use of nonlinear transmission lines (NLTLs) to replace the RF tubes in several applications as these new devices are all solid-state. For instance, lumped NLTLs can be used in the disruption of battlefield communications and drone telecommands as well in SAR radars for image remote sensing. There are two types of NLTLs: lumped lines with at least one nonlinear component (L or C) and nondispersive continuous ferrite loaded lines biased by an external axial magnetic field, known as gyromagnetic. With lumped NLTLs, our ongoing experiments have shown the operation of these devices at 300 MHz, using SiC Schottky diodes with a pair of DRG antennas for propagation1. With gyromagnetic lines, the recent results have demonstrated that these lines can also operate in the lower band range2 (200 MHz). For future tests, it is expected that these lines will reach operation frequencies up to 1.5 GHz using permanent magnets for compact space applications.

Document Title: Phase-Controlled Non-Uniformity Mitigation of Fuel Target Implosion in Heavy Ion Inertial Fusion
Authors: S. Kawata; K. Uchibori; H. Nakamura; A. I. Ogoyski
Author Affiliations: Utsunomiya University, Utsunomiya, Japan; Utsunomiya University, Utsunomiya, Japan; Utsunomiya University, Utsunomiya, Japan; Varna Technical University, Varna, Bulgaria
Publication Title: 2020 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science (ICOPS)
Abstract: The phase-controlled smoothing mechanism is applied to a direct-driven inertial fusion fuel target implosion in heavy ion inertial fusion (HIF). We have found a phase-controlled non-uniformity smoothing mechanism in plasmas1. In inertial confinement fusion, the fuel target should be imploded uniformly to obtain a high compression of the fusion DT fuel in order to reduce an input driver energy. The DT fuel density reaches about a thousand times the solid density. The fuel implosion uniformity requirement is stringent, and the implosion acceleration non-uniformity should be less than a few %. The phase-controlled non-uniformity is realized in the HIF fuel target implosion by the wobbling heavy ion beams (HIBs), and the implosion non-uniformity is successfully mitigated in HIF. In plasmas it would be difficult to measure the non-uniformity phase and amplitude. However, if the HIBs illumination non-uniformity may be oscillated, and the fuel target implosion non-uniformity would be controlled. The superimposition of the driver HIBs non-uniformity mitigates the original driver non-uniformity in the HIF target implosion1.

Publication Title: 2020 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science (ICOPS)
Abstract: This paper presents an exploration of low-temperature sterilization by an atmospheric pressure plasma jet(APPJ). This APPJ is driven by microwave which operation power is less than 25W and presents low temperature characteristics 1. Escherichia coli was treated in open environment by APPJ on the agar board, the scanning area is precisely controlled by X-Y stepping motor linear stage, germs on both treated and untreated area was cultured and counted. Experiments was performed with the distance between the edge of plasma jets and surface of the culture dish 0cm and 2.5cm. The results showed that compared with the untreated area, the number of germs in the plasma treated area was significantly reduced, multiple samples counted to zero, meanwhile, the temperature of agar was kept below 50°C during disinfection. These results indicated that this novel microwave plasma jet can realize the inactivation of E.coli without high temperature or chemical reagent and suggests that it is possible to realize sterilization by low temperature APPJ2, more germs will be tested in future work.

Document Title: A Plasma Jet Array Device for Transdermal Drug Delivery
Authors: Y. Lv; J. Duan; X. Lu
Author Affiliations: College of Electrical and Electronics Engineering, Huazhong Univ. of Sci. & Technol, Wuhan, Hubei, China; College of Electrical and Electronics Engineering, Huazhong Univ. of Sci. & Technol, Wuhan, Hubei, China; College of Electrical and Electronics Engineering, Huazhong Univ. of Sci. & Technol, Wuhan, Hubei, China
Publication Title: 2020 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science (ICOPS)
Abstract: Several research on the interaction between cold atmospheric plasma (CAP) and skin have shown that the great potential of CAP used in transdermal drug delivery (TDD). In this study, a plasma jet array device was used to enhance TDD efficiency [1]. Total discharge current was measured, the peak value is about 1A and the current duration time is about 100ns. Full thickness Porcine ear skin was exposed to the plasma jet during treatment, the treatment time was 3 min and 6 min. Paten blue was used as model drug to study the TDD efficiency using a Franz diffusion cell system[2]. Skin surface temperature during plasma treatment was also measured by an Infrared Thermometer. Results show that, after 3 min and 6min plasma treatment, the TDD efficiency was increased by nearly 5 times and 30 times, respectively. As for safety aspect, although the discharge current peak value is 1A, the duration time of the current is only 100ns. Temperature of skin surface during treatment is about 37.5°C same as human body temperature. Therefore, the plasma jet array in this study is no risk of electric shock and heat, suitable for human body use.

Document Title: High Power 2.85 GHz GaN RF Source for Direct Detection of Multipactor Research
Authors: B. Esser; Z. Shaw; J. C. Dickens; A. A. Neuber
Author Affiliations: Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Center for Pulsed Power and Power Electronics, Texas Tech University, Lubbock, TX, USA; Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Center for Pulsed Power and Power Electronics, Texas Tech University, Lubbock, TX, USA; Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Center for Pulsed Power and Power Electronics, Texas Tech University, Lubbock, TX, USA; Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Center for Pulsed Power and Power Electronics, Texas Tech University, Lubbock, TX, USA
Publication Title: 2020 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science (ICOPS)
Abstract: A pulsed 2.85 GHz RF source design with high average power is presented for use as the principle exciter in an experiment to directly detect multipactor. With a rated output power of 700 W each in long pulse mode (∼ 100 □s), four Cree GaN HEMTs are used to achieve a maximum of 2.8 kW rated output. A fifth HEMT is used to drive the four output devices with approximately 40 W each. A free running VCO with low tuning sensitivity is used which ensures a stable frequency output despite a noisy environment. Buffering and initial amplification is provided by an LNA with a TTL RF switch used to generate the pulses. With a rise time of 35 ns, this switch is fast enough to create reasonably square pulse edges. A microwave amplifier with 45 dB of gain provides the majority of the gain in the system and the power necessary for the final GaN stages, approximately 9 W. An in-line micrometer adjusted, continuously variable attenuator between LNA and TTL switch provides level control.

Document Title: Electromagnetic Launcher Speed Control with a Multilevel Fast Triggering Time Algorithm (MFTTA)
Authors: N. Tosun; H. Polat; O. Kevsan
Author Affiliations: Middle East Technical University, Ankara, Turkey; Middle East Technical University, Ankara, Turkey; Middle East Technical University, Ankara, Turkey
Publication Title: 2020 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science (ICOPS)
Abstract: Electromagnetic launchers can provide accurate speed control of a projectile compared to gun-powder based alternatives. However large-caliber launchers have several pulse power supply (PPS) modules connected in parallel to reach the required current levels. Determination of the triggering instants of these parallel PPS modules is a crucial part of the launch mechanism. The triggering instants do not only affect the exit velocity but also the forces on the armature which can lead to transition i.e. separation of the armature from the rails. In this study, a triggering sequence optimization method that is faster than other alternatives in the literature which uses evolutionary algorithms such as genetic algorithms (GA) and particle swarm optimization (PSO). Moreover, the proposed algorithm takes into account speed-dependent parasitic masses and transition phenomena. The number of evaluated simulations is considered as the determination of computational efficiency. GA and PSO models are implemented as benchmarks for the proposed model. 32 capacitive pulse power supply modules with 8 MJ total energy is used. With the achieved accuracy and speed, this study offer: An effective speed control algorithm with several physical constraints.

Document Title: High-Power and High-Frequency Gyrotrons: Development and Applications
Authors: M. Blank; P. Borchard; S. Cauffman; K. Felch
Author Affiliations: Communications & Power Industries, USA; Communications & Power Industries, USA; Communications & Power Industries, USA; Communications & Power Industries, USA
Publication Title: 2020 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science (ICOPS)
Abstract: Communications & Power Industries (CPI) is currently involved in the design and development of high-power and high-frequency gyrotron oscillators and amplifiers for a variety of applications, including fusion, spectroscopy, and millimeter-wave radar. The gyrotron's unique and unparalleled abilities to deliver high peak and average output powers at frequencies up to and into the terahertz regime render it an obvious choice for applications requiring powers from kilowatts to megawatts at hundreds of gigahertz. State-of-the-art gyrotrons for various applications as well as new directions in gyrotron research and development will be discussed. For example, experimental demonstrations of megawatt-class gyrotrons at 117.5 GHz1 for the DIII-D tokamak at General Atomics in the US, and 140 GHz2 for the Wendelstein 7-X stellarator at the Max-Planck-Institut fur Plasmasphysik in Germany and the EAST tokamak at CAS-ASIPP in China, will be described. In addition, recent advances in terahertz gyrotrons for dynamic nuclear polarization (DNP) enhanced nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy, including Bruker and CPI's family of commercial gyrotrons at 263, 395, 527, and 593 GHz3, will be detailed. Finally, gyrotrons for current and future highfrequency radar applications4 will be discussed.

Document Title: A Computational Study of Streamers Interacting with Dielectrics
Authors: A. Sun; X. Li; J. Teunissen
Author Affiliations: Xi'an Jiaotong University, Xi'an, Shaanxi, China; Xi'an Jiaotong University, Xi'an, Shaanxi, China; Centrum Wiskunde & Informatica, Amsterdam, The Netherlands
Publication Title: 2020 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science (ICOPS)
Abstract: Electric discharges along dielectric materials are common phenomena in electronics and high-voltage equipment. We here developed a 2D plasma fluid model to study the dynamics of both positive and negative surface streamers. The model is based on the Afivo-streamer code1, and improved to include dielectrics2. We simulate the process of streamers interacting with dielectrics, including inception besides the dielectric, attaching to and propagation over the dielectric surface. The results show that both positive and negative streamers are attracted by dielectrics. After attaching to the dielectric, both of them become thinner and faster, and the maximum electric field and electron density at the streamer head become higher than in bulk gas. However, positive streamers attach to the dielectric more rapidly, and have higher electric field and propagation velocity than negative streamers. In addition, a zone with high electric field but low electron density presents between positive streamers and dielectric surfaces. However, for a negative surface streamer, the maximum electron density shows up near the interface, while a strong electric field area presents inside the dielectric around the streamer head.

Document Title: Electron Cyclotron Emissions from Mirror Trapped Plasma: Observations and Modelling Results
Authors: B. Eliasson; D. C. Speirs; K. Ronald; A. D. R. Phelps; M. Viktorov; D. Mansfeld
Author Affiliations: SUPA, Department of Physics, University of Strathclyde, United Kingdom; SUPA, Department of Physics, University of Strathclyde, United Kingdom; SUPA, Department of Physics, University of Strathclyde, United Kingdom; SUPA, Department of Physics, University of Strathclyde, United Kingdom; Institute of Applied Physics of the Russian Academy of Sciences, Nizhny Novgorod, Russia; Institute of Applied Physics of the Russian Academy of Sciences, Nizhny Novgorod, Russia
Publication Title: 2020 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science (ICOPS)
Abstract: We report observations of electromagnetic emissions at electron cyclotron harmonics in a mirror-confined electron cyclotron resonance (ECR) plasma. The present research has achieved a new understanding of electron cyclotron instabilities by comparing measurements of emissions from a well-diagnosed laboratory plasma, with the predictions of analytical theory supported by Vlasov simulations. A notable success of this work is the revelation of the subtle effects that the presence of multi-component electron distribution functions involving a warm and ring-distributed 1 200–400 eV mirror-confined population of electrons and a much colder 1 eV component have on the excitation of electron cyclotron instabilities. This new understanding resulting from the research reported here is likely to have a significant impact on the many areas where electron cyclotron instabilities are of fundamental importance, including astrophysical plasmas2, near-Earth solar-terrestrial plasmas3, laboratory tokamak and stellarator fusion plasmas and electron cyclotron resonance sources.

Publication Title: 2020 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science (ICOPS)
Abstract: The relativistic magnetron with diffraction output (MDO) was predicted in particle-in-cell (PIC) simulations to achieve 70% electron beam-to-microwave power conversion efficiency. In experiments at the University of New Mexico (UNM) a conversion efficiency of >60% was measured in experiment until the cathode endcap flashed over, after which the efficiency dropped to below 40% [1]. Since these experiments the UNM group predicted similar efficiencies for an MDO powered using a virtual cathode [2]. The proposed advantage of operating the MDO with a virtual cathode as opposed to a physical cathode was the elimination of pulse shortening via AK gap closure. Finally, more recent work suggests that the use of a magnetic mirror to suppress axial leakage current can lead to maximal efficiency of an MDO driven by a virtual cathode [3]–[5]. This presentation will provide the latest experimental results on these subjects.

Document Title: Thz Radiation in Ion Focused Beam-Plasma System
Authors: Y. Gong; Q. Zhou; S. Yang; C. Tang
Author Affiliations: University of Electronic Science and Technology of China, Chengdu, China; University of Electronic Science and Technology of China, Chengdu, China; Sichuan University, Chengdu, China; Sichuan University, Chengdu, China
Publication Title: 2020 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science (ICOPS)
Abstract: When a relativistic electron beam moves through plasmas, electromagnetic (EM) radiation will be excited. And under different certain conditions, the electromagnetic radiation is relevant to a variety of novel mechanism. Firstly, the concept of plasma-based multistage virtual cathode radiation in beam-plasma system has been proposed. The formation of the virtual cathode is implemented, which shows that the virtual cathode is formed by a self-focusing relativistic electron beam, and the parametric regions of forming the virtual cathode are found[1]. Secondly, the THz electromagnetic radiation in beam-plasma system is investigated, and Cherenkov radiation is considered to be the mechanism of this study[2]. The electromagnetic radiation in radially non-uniform beam-plasma system also provide a clue that the beam-plasma system could produce THz electromagnetic radiation[3]. Thirdly, in an overdense plasma, high harmonic THz electromagnetic radiation could be excited by the interaction between plasma and a long electron beam, which leads to the resonance between the electron beam and the plasma wakefield[4]. Another scheme to generate high harmonic THz electromagnetic radiation is to take the self-modulation of the electron beam as a mode selection method. The self-modulation in transverse direction is to produce plasma wakefield and in the longitudinal direction the plasma wakefield will compress the bunches. The coupling of the harmonics of the modulated beam and the corresponding eigenmodes could result in the THz electromagnetic radiation[5]. Finally, some experiment results will be given.

Document Title: Modeling of Nanoparticle Growth and Charging in Flowing Plasmas
Authors: J. Polito; S. J. Lanham; M. J. Kushner; Z. Xiong; U. Kortshagen
Author Affiliations: University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI, USA; University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI, USA; University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI, USA; University of Minnesota, Minneapolis, MN, USA; University of Minnesota, Minneapolis, MN, USA
Publication Title: 2020 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science (ICOPS)
Abstract: Flowing low temperature plasmas are being investigated for synthesis of nanoparticles (a few to tens nm in size) having unique composition and crystallinity. NP properties such as size, composition, and luminescence can be tuned by adjusting plasma operating parameters, including pressure, gas flow rate, gas composition, and power deposition [1]. Previous work has shown that charging of the NPs plays an important role in NP characteristics due to its consequences for NP transport, heating and chemical reactivity. Computationally representing these dependencies in multi-dimensional models has been difficult due to the charge state (positive, negative or neutral) depending on the size and location (through plasmas properties) of the NP. For nanometer size particles, potentials and charges can be estimated using the Orbital Motion Limited Theory, though this model may overestimate the particle charge for larger sizes, and does not account for the statistical nature of charging of nanometer-sized particles. In this work we computationally investigate silicon NP synthesis on the reactor scale in a flowing, low pressure plasma sustained in Ar/SiH4. The Hybrid Plasma Equipment Model (HPEM) [2], a 2D reactor scale multi-physics model was used to track NP growth and charge fluctuations. Improvements to the HPEM, including algorithms accounting for particle growth, nucleation, agglomeration and charging will be discussed. Results for trends in silicon NP growth and charging as functions of operating parameters such as pressure and power deposition will be discussed. Comparison to experiments will also be discussed.

Document Title: Generation of Space Charge Self-Oscillations in a Vacuum Diode
Authors: M. Siman-Tov; J. G. Leopold; Y. E. Krasik
Author Affiliations: Physics Department Technion, Israel Institute of Technology, Haifa, Israel; Physics Department Technion, Israel Institute of Technology, Haifa, Israel; Physics Department Technion, Israel Institute of Technology, Haifa, Israel
Publication Title: 2020 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science (ICOPS)
Abstract: A practical method to inject an electron beam with a current amplitude exceeding the space-charge limit (SCL) of a vacuum diode was proposed [1]. The current is produced in an arrangement of three electrodes (a triode) consisting of an accelerating voltage gap followed by a decelerating gap. The cathode is required to emit an electron beam below the SCL limit of the accelerating gap. Thus, when the beam is not fully decelerated in the decelerating gap, it does not oscillate as it would in a reflex triode. This finite low energy electron beam flows into a third consecutive gap, which is considered to be the diode. When the current injected into the diode exceeds its SCL for a sufficiently low diode voltage, a virtual cathode forms and the beam self-oscillate at a frequency determined by the time-of-flight (TOF) of the electrons in the triode.

Author Affiliations: Plasma Physics Division, Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC, USA; Plasma Physics Division, Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC, USA; Plasma Physics Division, Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC, USA; Plasma Physics Division, Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC, USA; Plasma Physics Division, Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC, USA; Plasma Physics Division, Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC, USA; Plasma Physics Division, Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC, USA; Plasma Physics Division, Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC, USA; Plasma Physics Division, Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC, USA; Plasma Physics Division, Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC, USA; Department of Physics, Faculty of Electrical Engineering, CzechTechnical University in Prague, Prague, Czech Republic; Department of Physics, Faculty of Electrical Engineering, CzechTechnical University in Prague, Prague, Czech Republic; Department of Physics, Faculty of Electrical Engineering, CzechTechnical University in Prague, Prague, Czech Republic; Faculty of Physics, Weizmann Institute of Science, Rehovot, Israel; Faculty of Physics, Weizmann Institute of Science, Rehovot, Israel; Tech-X Corporation, Boulder, CO, USA; Tech-X Corporation, Boulder, CO, USA; Tech-X Corporation, Boulder, CO, USA; Confluent Sciences, Albuquerque, NM, USA
Publication Title: 2020 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science (ICOPS)
Abstract: Charged particle acceleration has been investigated in a dense plasma focus (DPF) driven by the Hawk pulsed-power generator at the Naval Research Laboratory. Neutron yields of over $5.0\times 10^{10}$ have been measured at a peak current of $\mathrm{I}=670\text{kA}$) significantly above the yield expected at this current based on purely I4.4 scaling from conventional DPFs. The high inductance (607 nH) and associated high voltage (640 kV) and fast rise time $(1.2 \mu \mathrm{s})$ of Hawk are unusual for a DPF driver, as is the initialization of the DPF using local injection of neutral gas and plasma into a vacuum chamber, rather than a conventional neutral gas fill. This method of initialization allows for the selection of an extensive array of initial conditions. A subset of those initial conditions has been explored in conjunction with multi-dimensional MHD simulations to affect the energy of the accelerated ions, as measured by an ion multi-pinhole camera, the neutron yield, as measured by rhodium-foil activation counters, and the end point energy of the emitted neutrons, as measured by neutron time-of-flight detectors.

Document Title: Study Of single and Dual Frequency Rf Driven Multipactor on a Dielectric in the Frequency Domain
Authors: A. Iqbal; P. Wong; J. Verboncoeur; P. Zhang
Author Affiliations: Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Michigan State University, East Lansing, Michigan, USA; Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Michigan State University, East Lansing, Michigan, USA; Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Michigan State University, East Lansing, Michigan, USA; Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Michigan State University, East Lansing, Michigan, USA
Publication Title: 2020 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science (ICOPS)
Abstract: Multipactor [1]–[4] is an AC discharge in which a high frequency rf field creates an electron avalanche sustained through secondary electron emission from a metallic or dielectric surface. This work presents the frequency domain study of multipactor discharge on a single dielectric surface with rf electric fields of single or two carrier frequencies. We employ a one-dimensional multiparticle Monte Carlo (MC) simulation scheme with adaptive time steps to obtain the temporal profiles [5] of the surface charging field. By performing Discrete Fourier Transform (DFT) on the temporal profiles, we characterize the amplitude spectrum [6], [7] of the surface charging fields in the ac saturation state.

Document Title: Unraveling Laser-Driven Ultrafast Plasma Dynamics Inside Solids
Authors: M. Shaikh; A. D. Lad; J. Jha; D. Sarkar; S. Tata; G. Chatterjee; I. Dey; K. Jana; P. K. Singh; G. R. Kumar; G. Birindelli; V. T. Tikhonchuk; K. Pepitone; P. P. Rajeev
Author Affiliations: Tata Institute of Fundamental Research, Mumbai, India; Tata Institute of Fundamental Research, Mumbai, India; Tata Institute of Fundamental Research, Mumbai, India; Tata Institute of Fundamental Research, Mumbai, India; Tata Institute of Fundamental Research, Mumbai, India; Tata Institute of Fundamental Research, Mumbai, India; Tata Institute of Fundamental Research, Mumbai, India; Tata Institute of Fundamental Research, Mumbai, India; Tata Institute of Fundamental Research, Mumbai, India; Tata Institute of Fundamental Research, Mumbai, India; Centre Lasers Intenses et Applications, University of Bordeaux-CNRS-CEA, Talence, France; Centre Lasers Intenses et Applications, University of Bordeaux-CNRS-CEA, Talence, France; Beam Department (BE), CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Central Laser Facility, Rutherford Appleton Laboratory, Oxfordshire, United Kingdom
Publication Title: 2020 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science (ICOPS)
Abstract: Intense femtosecond lasers, focused on a solid surface, can accelerate ultrashort pulses of electrons to near-light speeds, launching megaampere currents into the solid material behind. Understanding the transport of these relativistic electrons through solids is central to many areas in laser-driven plasmas and their translational research, ranging from laser-driven fusion to the production of micro-accelerators for industrial and medical applications. In particular, the “transit time” of these relativistic electrons through the material - i.e. the duration of their lifetime inside the solid - is an important parameter that determines the efficiency of energy transfer to the lattice. For example this is critical for determining the efficacy of laser-driven particle sources for therapeutic applications. However, due to the inaccessibility of the side-products from this interaction, very little is known about the time the electrons spend inside a solid and no reliable methods exist to delineate this information. We have recently shown that “real-time” measurements of the transition of relativistic electrons through a solid dielectric can be obtained by monitoring their Cherenkov emission through an ultrafast-laser-driven Kerr-gate. The Kerr-gate provides an ultrafast shutter-speed camera to freeze-frame the electron motion inside the material, yielding invaluable information about their dynamics and lifetime inside solids1.

Publication Title: 2020 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science (ICOPS)
Abstract: A current free low pressure plasma expanding in a diverging magnetic field can spontaneously generate current free double layers (CFDL)1,2. The energetic ion beam generated at the downstream of the CFDL gives a new perspective to the study of such double layers3. This supersonic ion beam can explain different space and laboratory plasma phenomena4, from the acceleration of the plasma particles in the aurora to the design of a helicon double layer thruster.

Document Title: A New Algorithm for Simulating Space-Charge Limited Flow
Authors: P. Stoltz; D. N. Smithe; A. Chap; J. Luginsland
Author Affiliations: Tech-X Corporation, Boulder, CO, USA; Tech-X Corporation, Boulder, CO, USA; Tech-X Corporation, Boulder, CO, USA; Confluent Sciences, LLC, Albuquerque, NM, USA
Publication Title: 2020 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science (ICOPS)
Abstract: In particle-in-cell simulation, generating a space-charge limited electron source presents challenges due to the steep gradients in electron density and electric field infinitesimally close to such an emitting surface. Simulating accurate emission current densities is essential for modeling complex microwave device geometries such as that of the magnetron. These simulations are complicated by the device geometry, which is resolved using cut-cells on a Cartesian grid. We will discuss modeling strategies for space-charge limited emission on planar cut-cell boundaries, and present convergence studies to evaluate their accuracy in both simple and complex geometries. As applications, we show simulation of explosive emission in a magnetron and magnetically insulated line oscillator (MILO). For the MILO, we show that this new emission algorithm results in the appearance of harmonics of the main frequency in the absorbed current.

Publication Title: 2020 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science (ICOPS)
Abstract: Pulsed power systems are developed to release, in a short time, a significant amount of stored energy. This requires the design of devices and circuits that must withstand high amounts of power. A typical pulsed power application is composed of a high-voltage capacitive storage source and a closing switch to transfer the energy to a load. Marx generators, Tesla transformers, or capacitor banks are usually used to drive Pulse Forming Lines (PFL) or Networks (PFN) to provide 106 to 1014 W within 10−10 to 10−5 s1. A fundamental element driving the performance of pulsed power applications is the high current switch. Depending on the required output rise-time, spark gaps or high-current solid-state switches are typically used.

Document Title: Pulsed Laser Deposition: A Flexible Tool for the Synthesis of Advanced Functional Materials
Author Affiliations: INRS-Energie Matériaux Télécommunications 1650 Lionel-Boulet Boulevard, Varennes, QC, Canada
Publication Title: 2020 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science (ICOPS)
Abstract: Innovation in materials science and engineering resides in our ability to design new materials with tailored properties (electri cal, optical, magnetic, etc.) by controlling their nanostructure. One of the most powerful means to uniquely arrange matter at such scale is to use plasmas due to their unique ability to provi de simultaneously a variety of particles with different energies such as ions, neutral atoms and radicals. In this presentation, w e will focus on the synthesis of metal insulator transition (MIT) materials using the Pulsed Laser Deposition (PLD) tech nique that allows an excellent control of material stoichiometr y and density as well as of the material nanostructure. Vanadiu m dioxide (VO2) and samarium nickelate (SmNiO3) are particularly interesting MIT materials as their electrical resistivity as well as their infrared and terahertz (THz) reflectivity undergo significant changes across the thermo/photo-induced MIT, at transition temperatures TMIT ≈ 68 °C and 130 °C respectively. In a series of investigations, our group has examined the physics governing the MIT of VO2 and SmNiO3 thin films and has explored new application opportunities including uncooled bolometers, and smart radiator devices for space applications.

Document Title: Effective Pair Potentials for Dense Plasma Applications
Authors: L. J. Stanek; M. S. Murillo; R. C. Clay
Author Affiliations: Department of Computational Mathematics, Science, and Engineering, Michigan State University, East Lansing, MI, USA; Department of Computational Mathematics, Science, and Engineering, Michigan State University, East Lansing, MI, USA; Sandia National Laboratories High Energy-Density Physics, Theory Organization, Albuquerque, NM, USA
Publication Title: 2020 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science (ICOPS)
Abstract: Transport is nearly impossible to measure in high energy-density (HED) systems and we rely on high-fidelity computational methods to determine their values. The most accurate methods become computationally expensive in HED and therefore cannot be used. Pair potential molecular dynamics provides an avenue for obtaining transport coefficients rapidly but with unknown accuracy. Our goal is to use high-fidelity simulation data to create effective pair potentials that are more accurate in the HED regime.

Document Title: Electrostatic Wave Dynamics in a Dense Relativistically Degenerate Magnetised Plasma
Author Affiliations: Department of Mathematics, School of Applied Sciences, University of Science and Technology, Meghalaya, India
Publication Title: 2020 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science (ICOPS)
Abstract: The propagation of three-dimensional (3-D)electrostatic solitary and shock waves with weakly relativistic and ultra-relativistic degenerate electrons and positrons is investigated in a dense magnetized plasma. For this purpose, a 3-D Zakharov-Kuznetsov-Burgers (Z-K-B) equation is derived from the pair of ion continuity and momentum equation with bulk viscosity among ion fluids, and degenerate electrons and positrons. The effect of mass of pair of ions, positron concentration, magnetic field strength and the Fermi temperature of weakly relativistic and ultra-relativistic degenerate electrons and positrons are studied in the present work. The Burgers term in our system is responsible for shock structures in pair ion plasmas. Analytical prediction and numerical analysis enable us to know that the wave yields solitary profile in absence of collisions and exhibits both oscillatory and monotonic depending on collisions between pair of ions and balanced status of diisipation and dispersion. Moreover, it is exhibited that the chaotic dynamics occur when the perturbed Z-K-B equation is perturbed by external force, and we use power spectrum, phase projection, and Lyapunov exponents to observe both weak and developed chaos. For illustration purposes, we have considered the astrophysical parameters in a white dwarf.

Document Title: Laser-Induced Fluorescence Spectroscopic Analysis of U and Pu Plasmas
Authors: S. S. Harilal; E. J. Kautz; M. C. Phillips; C. M. Murzyn; J. B. Martin; S. S. Mitra; S. E. Bisson
Author Affiliations: Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, WA, USA; Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, WA, USA; University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ, USA; Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM, USA; Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM, USA; Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM, USA; Sandia National Laboratories, Livermore, CA, USA
Publication Title: 2020 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science (ICOPS)
Abstract: Currently, actinide (eg. U, Pu, etc.) analysis at various facilities has been carried out using inductively-coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS), inductively-coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES), and thermal ionization spectrometry and all these techniques need extensive, and hence time-consuming, laboratory-based sample preparation. Optical spectroscopic tools such as emission, absorption, and fluorescence have the potential to perform in-field, rapid, and non-contact actinide analysis. Laser-induced breakdown spectroscopy which employs emission spectroscopy of laser-produced plasma was previously used for U plasma analysis including isotopic detection.1 However, the use of emission-based spectroscopic tools for actinide analysis is always challenging considering the extremely congested spectra of all actinides including U and Pu. For example, there exist nearly 100,000 transitions in the UV-VIS spectral range for uranium neutrals and singly ionized species. In addition to these, the emission spectroscopic tools are constrained by instrumental broadening which dictates the available spectral resolution. In this context, laser-induced fluorescence (LIF) and laser-absorption spectroscopy (LAS) are useful tools for obtaining high-resolution spectral features, linewidths, isotopic shifts and hyperfine structures. Although extensive studies have been carried out on optical spectroscopy of U, data on the spectroscopy of Pu is very limited.

Document Title: The Generation of Coherent and Tunable Terahertz Radiation from Plasma Modulated Electron Beams
Authors: H. Zhang; I. Konoplev; G. Doucas; J. Smith
Author Affiliations: College of Advanced Interdisciplinary Studies, National University of Defense Technology, Changsha, P R. China; Department of Physics, John Adams Institute, University of O xford, DWB, Oxford, UK; Department of Physics, John Adams Institute, University of O xford, DWB, Oxford, UK; Sci-Tech Daresbury, Tech-X UK Ltd, The Innovation Centre, Cheshire, UK
Publication Title: 2020 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science (ICOPS)
Abstract: Terahertz (THz) radiation based technological solutions have applications in many areas including information and communication technology, biology, medical sciences, non-destructive detection and security. With the development of accelerator technologies around the world, there has been a growing interest in the generation of THz radiation driven by a linear accelerator (LINAC). The crucial part in the generation of the tunable THz radiation is the production of microbunched electron beams with picosecond (ps) and sub-ps periodicity. A long electron beam propagating through a plasma channel can be modulated and divided into a train of microbunches, with the periodicity defined by the plasma frequency. We proposed a method of microbunched beam conditioning to allow Smith-Purcell THz radiation generation. The great advantage of the beam plasma modulation is its simplicity, as the microbunch periodicity can be tuned by changing the gas pressure in a plasma capillary and thus the plasma density and plasma frequency. We show that this approach has the potential to generate coherent and tunable THz radiation.

Publication Title: 2020 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science (ICOPS)
Abstract: In recent years electromagnetic wave-driven plasma sources for focused ion beams (FIB) have attracted considerable attention1. However, developing such plasma sources for FIB is nontrivial and can pose mighty challenges. Often a micro-meter size beam needs to be extracted to maintain a small object size for demagnification, thereby demanding that the plasma source be as small as possible. The situation is exacerbated in case of microwave driven plasma sources because of geometrical cutoff limitation, which demands a minimum chamber dimension for wave propagation and subsequent plasma generation2. Additionally, the density cutoff limitation is encountered when the plasma frequency becomes larger than the wave frequency. The two limitations are often inextricably intertwined and pose considerable confrontation for wave-particle sustainability, often rendering surprising observations3.

Document Title: Global Model Development Using Least-Squares Weighted Residual Methods
Authors: T. G. Jenkins; S. N. Averkin
Author Affiliations: Tech-X Corporation, Boulder, CO, USA; Tech-X Corporation, Boulder, CO, USA
Publication Title: 2020 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science (ICOPS)
Abstract: A popular paradigm for the study of complex plasma discharges is the global model, which can provide estimates of volume-averaged plasma parameters of interest (number densities, temperatures, viable chemical reaction paths, etc.). Although global models are useful for parameter scoping, they cannot generally provide information on the spatial distribution of these physics processes. In this work, we present a reformulation of the global model equations using numerical methods that approximately capture these spatial dependencies. Plasma quantities are expressed in terms of rational functional representations with undetermined coefficients. Least-squares weighted residual methods are then applied to the ensuing global model equations to determine these coefficients in a way that minimizes various norms (L2, L-inf, etc.). Optimal coefficients corresponding to a given norm can thus be computed for all plasma components, permitting approximate profiles to be constructed.

Abstract: Vacuum integrated technology has been a favorable choice for the generation of high frequency, high power radiation source because of their ability to handle high power in a compact size. W band (75GHz-110GHz) is considerably a high frequency band and with the increase in the frequency, the wavelength decreases which provides a limitation in developing structures with the desired machining tolerances and surface finish [1]–[3]. Machining tolerances and surface roughness are the important parameters for the propagation of RF signal and can considerably effect the characteristics performance of the vacuum tube [3]–[4]. In this paper a beam wave interaction structure for W-Band frequency has been fabricated in two halves by wire EDM micro fabrication technique and then both the parts were integrated to form a staggered double vane structure. An extensive study of SEM results of the fabricated structure accounts for the dimensional deviation of 10 microns. The interaction structure has a tapered region to ensure low impedance mismatch and better coupling with the WR-10 waveguide ports of VNA. Consequently, the fabricated structure was used to perform the cold test analysis. A waveguide casing was fabricated in accordance with dimensions of WR-10 waveguide for cold test analysis. The interaction structure was assembled inside the casing and connected with the VNA ports. The cold test analysis parameters like S11 and S12 are estimated to be less than −20 dB and near to 0 dB respectively.

Abstract: Due to the scientific potentials of terahertz spectrum and prospect applications in spectroscopy, imaging and communication etc., the development of broadband and high power terahertz coherent radiation source has become extremely urgent nowadays. Based on the planar electron beam and new-type planar miniaturization staggered double vane (SDV) slow wave structure (SWS), the exploration on the multi-mode and high-mode beam wave interaction system can significantly broaden the bandwidth and increase the output power for such travelling wave tube (TWT) in terahertz band. Thus, this paper has focused on the development of the multi-mode and high-mode SDV-TWT with their frequency structures and beam wave interaction systems for the periodic SDV-SWS, exploring the high frequency characteristics of multi-mode and high-mode transmission dispersion, high coupling impedance, mode convert, broadband matching of input and output coupling system as well as the high power window. we proposed the SDV-SWS vacuum electron devices for TWT to produce several kilo-watts peak power at 0.1THz and above several hundred-watts at 0.22THz, with the 3dB bandwidth about 30- 70GHz using two-mode beam-wave interactions. Also, the output characteristics of mode TM31 SDV-TWT at 340GHz is designed, a maximum output power of 40W near the center frequency with the gain of 36dB and a 3dB bandwidth of 38GHz is achieved. Document Title: Computational Modelling of RONS Generation and its Enhancement by UV Photolysis in Plasma-Liquid System
Authors: H. Lee; J. Y. Park; W. Choe; S. Park
Author Affiliations: Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, Daejeon, Republic of Korea; Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, Daejeon, Republic of Korea; Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, Daejeon, Republic of Korea; Plasma Technology Reesearch Center, Gunsan-si, Jeollabuk-do, Republic of Korea
Publication Title: 2020 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science (ICOPS)
Abstract: Active attempts have been ongoing to utilize abundant reactive oxygen and nitrogen species (RONS) produced by atmospheric pressure plasmas in various fields such as biomedicine, agriculture, and food cycle. One of the interesting ways of utilizing RONS is via the plasma-treated water (PTW) because PTW effectively maintains a large amount of RONS and relevant intermediates for a long post-discharge period. While applying PTW containing RONS for applications, identifying the key chemical species and their kinetics is a prerequisite because they strongly depend on application systems [1]. In this presentation, our numerical code developed to obtain spatiotemporal distribution of RONS in a plasma-water system will be discussed. The code calculates RONS concentration in the 1D gas and liquid model from the 0D plasma global model with Boltzmann equation solver (BOLSIG+), to calculate mean electron energy and mobility [2], [3]. In the model, the decomposition reaction of chemical species by photons, i.e. photolysis, was included to predict how chemical products change depending on the spectrum and intensity of UV light source. The result shows that the concentrations of O3, H2O2, and NOx are higher than other species in the entire gas region, and O3, H2O2, and NO3− concentrations are higher than other species in the liquid region. hydroxyl radical (OH) and nitric oxide (NO) and other radicals in the plasma region generated these species by reactions with the electron, ions, and radicals. However, OH and NO concentration is relatively low due to their high reactivity. By UV photolysis, O3, NO2, HNO2, and NO3− were decomposed, resulting in the additional production of OH NO in PTW. The developed model gives valuable insights into controlling the RONS generation in the UV-combined PTW system, and it will provide a better understanding of the change in chemical composition of PTW in the presence of a light source.

Abstract: The Z-machine at Sandia National Laboratories is instrumental in plasma physics research across a range of applications. University-scale z-pinch experiments, such as gas-puff z-pinches, can inform the high-value experiments conducted on the Z facility. A gas-puff z-pinch requires gas to be puffed into the anode-cathode gap, which is then pulsed with a high voltage1. The gas is ionized, accelerated, and compressed as the current flows across the electrodes, allowing for study of pinch phenomena including fusion reactions2. The initial ionization condition of the gas-puff prior to compression is poorly understood. Additionally, how this affects fusion, which is largely the result of micro- pinch instabilities, is also poorly understood. We report on the progress made in developing this experimental capability on the MAIZE Linear Transformer Driver at the University of Michigan.

Abstract: Solid state high power microwave sources eliminate some of the challenges associated with vacuum devices, including size, repetition rate, and required auxiliary systems. Nonlinear transmission lines (NLTLs) minimize the auxiliary systems required, reduce the system size, and increase the repetition rate. NLTLs utilize the nonlinearity of materials' voltage-dependent permittivity, such as barium strontium titanate (BST), and/or current-dependent permeability, such as nickel zinc ferrite (NZF), to create an electromagnetic shockwave1. Because controlling inclusion volume fraction in a composite can tune electromagnetic properties2, we examine the feasibility of tuning NLTL performance by controlling the volume loading of BST and/or NZF in a single line. Other studies have shown that coating BST with NZF and dispersing the ceramic powder in a plastic matrix can increase the composite permittivity while decreasing the magnetic loss for use in high energy density capacitors1.

Authors: L. H. Lyu; Y. C. Huang
Author Affiliations: Institute of Space Science and Engineering, National Central University, Taoyuan, Taiwan; Institute of Space Science and Engineering, National Central University, Taoyuan, Taiwan
Publication Title: 2020 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science (ICOPS)
Abstract: A new mechanism has been proposed to explain the observed quasi-periodic broad-band whistler-chorus emissions in the inner magnetosphere of the Earth.[1] We show that the gyro motion and bounce motion of the substorm injected energetic electrons can emit broad-band backscattering chorus waves with frequencies below the electron gyrofrequency. The energy expansions of the chorus waves are studied based on their group-velocity distributions. The group-velocity distribution of the whistler-chorus waves can explain the frequency gap near half of the electron gyrofrequency. Our results indicate that the frequency gap is not a result of Landau damping but a consequence of the highly field- aligned expansion of chorus waves at the specific frequencies.

Abstract: Multipactor discharge is a resonant phenomenon that can be initiated in vacuum under RF excitation, giving rise to charge growth over time. The electron dynamics under such collisionless conditions has been researched by kinetic Monte Carlo and magnetohydrodynamic models in the past. As an alternative, we develop and present studies of a Vlasov equation based numerical model to calculate multipactor susceptibility in common microwave structures [1]. In contrast to kinetic models, utilization of the Vlasov equation permits the continuous treatment of the electron distribution in phase space, thereby capturing all statistical outcomes in a single calculation. To address the computational demand of the Vlasov equation, parallel computing techniques are utilized.

Publication Title: 2020 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science (ICOPS)
Abstract: A common objective in plasma etching is to form high aspect ratio (HAR) features into a patterned substrate. Modelling ions travelling through HAR features helps in quantifying etching effects as a function of ions energy and direction to optimize etching processes. Since those ions generated from plasma sheath are both energetic and directional, the collisions between ions and side walls are glancing-angle scatterings when ions travelling through HAR features, most with angles of incidence greater than 80 degrees. These glancing-angle events depend on both incident energies and angles, generating a range of exit energies and angles after the scattering event, modifying the effective distribution as a process moves deeper into HAR features. This work will focus on glancing-angle scattering as a function of incident ions energy and direction, material types, and material surface roughness. The motivation is to provide this data to improve etch process as well as feature-level simulation efforts to elucidate the effects on the profile of HAR features.

Document Title: Physics of Electron Emission from Two-Dimensional Nanomaterials
Author Affiliations: Science and Mathematics Cluster, Singapore University of Technology and Design (SUTD), Singapore
Publication Title: 2020 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science (ICOPS)
Abstract: Nanomaterials with reduced dimensionality offers a new paradigm in the design of nanoscale vacuum devices1, 2. Because of the reduced dimensionality and the exotic energy band structure of two-dimensional (2D) materials, the physics of electron emission becomes drastically different compared to the conventional bulk materials. In this talk, we review the physics of electron emission from 2D nanomaterials. We show that, in the thermionic emission regime, the electron emission characteristics can be well-captured by a universal scaling laws broadly applicable to wide classes of 2D materials3. The modelling of electron field emission from 2D semimetals of various band topology will also be introduced. As electron emission is a critically important interfacial charge transport process in both solid/vacuum and solid/solid interfaces, the physics-based electron emission models4, 5 developed recently shall provide a theoretical foundation for both the fundamental study of surface physics, and the practical engineering of solid-state and vacuum electronic devices based on 2D materials and their heterostructures.

Experimentally, from the probe measurements they obtained the plasma parameters viz. electron temperature (Te) and electron density (ne) which they compared with the results obtained from their basic plasma model. They observed significant differences in their Te and ne values. In order to understand this difference, in the present work, we developed a detailed collisional radiative (CR) model on their OES and OAS measurements. In such LT plasma, electron impact excitation (EIE) and de-excitation processes are prominent kinetic processes. The proper inclusion of these processes in a CR model requires the reliable EIE cross-sections data of various transitions. We calculated the cross-sections for different transitions from the ground $2p^{6}$ state to the fine structure levels (FSLs) of $2p^{5}3s, 2p^{5}3p,\ 2p^{5}3d,\ 2p^{5}4s$ and $2p^{5}4p$ configurations as well as from $2p^{5}3s$ configuration to the $2p^{5}3p$ and $2p^{5}4p$ configurations using the relativistic distorted wave theory [2]. The present model considers 42 FSLs along with with the ground state of Ne and Ne+ and different population transfer kinetic processes among the fine structure level. Plasma parameters viz. ne, Te and the $1s_{i}$ level populations are obtained from the model at different pressures 5-25 mTorr and are found in excellent agreement with the corresponding measurements [1].

Document Title: Electron Dynamics within a Magnetically Insulated Transmission Line Containing a Load
Authors: M. H. Hess; E. G. Evstatiev
Author Affiliations: Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM, USA; Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM, USA
Publication Title: 2020 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science (ICOPS)
Abstract: The physics of electron flow within an open-ended cylindrically symmetric magnetically insulated transmission line (MITL) has been previously studied in great detail. In this work, we investigate how the behavior of MITL electron flow is modified in the presence of a load, i.e. where the circuit voltage goes to zero. Specifically, we look at two MITL geometries with loads, namely a radial MITL and a MITL with a spherical bend. We model and compare the electric fields and electron flow for these two cases using analytical/numerical methods and the code EMPIRE developed at Sandia National Laboratories. The analytical field calculations allow for a Lagrangian/Hamiltonian approach while the simulations of particle trajectories accurately model gyro-motion of electrons. Qualitatively, we find that at distances far from the load, the particle's motion is largely due to ExB drift motion towards the load. Close to the load, however, the particle's motion is largely due to grad B drift with possible ExB drift enhancement due to a MITL bend. In addition, we discuss when the guiding center drift theory does not agree with full kinetic solutions of electron MITL motion.

Due to elimination of external magnetic field, the source becomes very compact [2]. The electron beam in such sources can be generated from the cold plasma cathode electron gun [3]. The electron beam propagates inside the interaction structure and ionize the gas molecule which leads to formation of ion channel for focusing of the electron beam. The plasma inside the interaction structure is very important parameter for transfer of the energy of the electron beam to the RF wave. Therefore, in this work simulation study has been performed for analyzing the behavior of plasma assisted W-band interaction structure. Simulation study has been carried out for different gas pressures ranging between 18–25 Pa and applied gap voltage 20–40 kV. The axial profile of plasma parameters has been evaluated under these applied conditions for the design of W-band planar staggered double-vane interaction structure.
